speaker: narrator
text: Chapter 1 of True Stories of Crime from the District Attorney's Office

speaker: narrator
text: This is a Libravox Recording. All Libravox recordings are in the public domain.

speaker: narrator
text: For more information or to volunteer, please visit Libravox.org

speaker: narrator
text: Recording by Colleen McMahon.

speaker: narrator
text: True Stories of Crime from the District Attorney's Office by Arthur Cheney Train.

speaker: narrator
text: Preface

speaker: narrator
text: The narratives composing this book are literally true stories of crime

speaker: narrator
text: In a majority of the cases, the author conducted the prosecution himself, and therefore may claim to have a personal knowledge of that whereof he speaks.

speaker: narrator
text: While no confidence has been abused, no essential facts have been omitted, distorted, or colored, and the accounts themselves being all matters of public record may be easily verified.

speaker: narrator
text: The scenes recorded here are not literature but history, and the characters who figure in them are not puppets of the imagination,

speaker: narrator
text: but men and women who lived and schemed, laughed, sinned, and suffered, and paid the price when the time came most of them without flinching.

speaker: narrator
text: A few of those who read these pages may profit perhaps by their example. Others may gain somewhat in their knowledge of life and human nature, but all will agree that there are books in the running books, even if the streams be turbid, and sermons and stones, though these be the hearts of men.

speaker: narrator
text: If in some instances the narratives, savor in treatment more affiction than a fact, the writer must plead guilty to having fallen under the spell of the romance of his subject, and he prophecy the excuse that whereas such tales have lost nothing in accuracy, they may have gained in the truth of their final impression.

speaker: narrator
text: Arthur Cheney, Criminal Courts Building, New York City, April 20th, 1908

speaker: narrator
text: On a sultry August afternoon in 1903, a dapper, if somewhat anemic young man, entered the Broadway store of Rogers, Pete, and Company in New York City and asked to be allowed to look at a suit of clothes.

speaker: narrator
text: Having selected one to his fancy and arranged for some alterations, he produced from his wallet a check for $280, drawn to the order of George B. Lang, and signed E. Beer Stop, and remarked to the attentive salesman.

speaker: narrator
text: I haven't got quite enough cash with me to pay for these, but I have been intending to cash this check all the afternoon. Of course, you don't know me, or even that my name is Lang, but if you will forward the check to the bank they will certify it, and tomorrow I will send for the suit and the balance of the money.

speaker: narrator
text: Certainly Mr. Lang replied the salesman, I will hold the suit and the money to await your orders.

speaker: narrator
text: The customer thanked him and took his departure. The check was sent to the bank, the bank certified it, then cancelled its certification and returned to the check to Rogers Pete and Company, and the store detectives, having communicated with police headquarters, anxiously awaited the arrival of Mr. Lang's messenger.

speaker: narrator
text: Their efforts were rewarded a couple of days later by the appearance at the store of a lad who presented a written order, inscribed upon the back of an envelope, bearing a cancelled stamp, and addressed to George B. Lang, number 13, West 26th Street, New York City, which red as follows.

speaker: narrator
text: Rogers Pete and Company, please give to bearer the clothes I purchased on Tuesday, suit, pants, S. C. C. C. and also kindly put change in envelope in inside C. C. C. C. C.

speaker: narrator
text: pocket, trusting the alterations or satisfactory, and thanking you in advance for the favor and for past curses, I am respectfully yours, George B. Lang.

speaker: narrator
text: The boy was immediately placed under arrest, and after proclaiming his own innocence, and both separating that he was only doing an errand for a gent who was waiting close by, was directed to return with his bundle as if nothing had occurred.

speaker: narrator
text: This he did, and Mr. George B. Lang was soon in the clutches of the law.

speaker: narrator
text: Interrogated by his captors, the supposed Lang admitted that his real name was James Parker, that he lived at 110 West 38th Street, and only requested that his wife be immediately notified of what had happened.

speaker: narrator
text: At headquarters, the prisoner was identified as a gentleman who had been very actively engaged during the preceding months, in passing bad checks throughout the city.

speaker: narrator
text: His more recent operations, having consisted in cashing a check on the Lincoln National Bank for $160 on July 20th, one for $290 on the same bank on July 30th, still another for $51050 on August 4th, and one for $44050 on the National Shoe and Leather Bank to bearer on August 8th.

speaker: narrator
text: This last, in some inexplicable way, had been cashed at the very bank itself.

speaker: narrator
text: Believing that the forger had at last been caught, the precinct detectives later on during the evening of Parker's arrest, visited West 38th Street, and on inquiring for Mrs. Parker, were introduced to a young girl of attractive appearance to whom they delivered their unwelcome message.

speaker: narrator
text: Mrs. Parker seemed overwhelmed at the news, and strongly asserted her confidence in her husband's innocence of any wrongdoing, having performed the errand the officers departed.

speaker: narrator
text: A certain, inerradicable jealousy has always existed between the plain clothesmen of the various precincts, and the sleuths attached to the central office.

speaker: narrator
text: And in this instance, the precinct men, having gained the credit for the arrest, it did not occur to them as necessary to communicate the knowledge of their acquaintance with Mrs. Parker to detective sergeant's pee body in Clark, originally assigned it headquarters to investigate the case.

speaker: narrator
text: It seemed, however, to pee body very unlikely that Parker had conducted his operations alone, and he therefore once inquired at the tombs what character visitors came to see the prisoner.

speaker: narrator
text: The gate man replied that as yet none had arrived, at that very instant, a young girl stepped to the wicket, and asked if she could be allowed to see Mr. James Parker.

speaker: narrator
text: It took the detective, but a moment to run across to the criminal court's building, and to telephone the warden to detain her temporarily, and then to refuse her request.

speaker: narrator
text: Five minutes later, the girl emerged, disconsolently, from the tombs, and boarded a car going up town.

speaker: narrator
text: Peabody followed her to 110 West 38th Street, not for an instant supposing that the girl herself could be the forger, but believing that possibly through her he might learn of other members of the gang, and secure additional evidence against Parker himself.

speaker: narrator
text: Of course, no intelligent person today supposes that, outside of Serconan Doyle's interesting novels, detectives seek the baffling criminal by means of analyzing cigar butts, magnifying thumb marks, or specializing in the various perfumes in favor among the fair sex, or by any of those complicated brain-feteking processes of ratio-sination indulged in by our old friend Mr. Sherlock Holmes.

speaker: narrator
text: There are still, however, genuine detectives, and some of them are to be found upon the New York police force.

speaker: narrator
text: The magnifying glass is not one of the ordinary tools of the professional sleuth, and if he carries a pistol at all, it is because the police rules require it.

speaker: narrator
text: While those cases may be numbered upon the fingers of two hands, whereas own hair and whiskers were not entirely sufficient for his purposes in the course of his professional career.

speaker: narrator
text: The next morning, Peabody Donz, the most disreputable suit in his wardrobe, neglected his ordinary visit to the barber, and called it 110 West 38th Street, being, of course, at this time entirely unaware of the fact that the girl was Parker's wife.

speaker: narrator
text: He found her sitting in a rocking chair in a comfortable well-fornished room and reading a magazine.

speaker: narrator
text: Assuming an expression of sheepish inanity, he informed her that he was an old pal of gyms, who had been so unfortunate as to be locked up in the same cell with him at headquarters, and that the latter was in desperate need of morphine.

speaker: narrator
text: That Parker was a habitual user of the drug, could be easily seen from the most casual inspection, but that it would prove an open sesame to the girl's confidence was, as the detective-effrored testified, a hundred to one shot.

speaker: narrator
text: Poor Jim exclaimed the girl. Couldn't she smuggle some into the tombs for him? Peabody took the hint. Of course he could. It would be a hard job, those turnkeys were so suspicious.

speaker: narrator
text: But he could do it for her if anybody could. He rambled on telling his experiences with Parker in the past, how he had been in a myro reformatory and elsewhere with him, and gaining each moment valuable information from the girl's exclamations, questions, and expression.

speaker: narrator
text: He soon learned that she was Parker's wife, that they were living in comparative comfort, and that she was an exceedingly clever and well-educated woman, but she said nothing during the conversation which would indicate that she knew anything of her husband's offenses, or any persons connected with them.

speaker: narrator
text: After a few moments, the girl slipped on her coat and hat, and the two started down to the tombs, where, by pre-arrangement with the officials, the detective succeeded in convincing her that he had been able to send into her husband a small hypodermic syringe, commonly called the needles, which she had purchased at a neighboring drugstore.

speaker: narrator
text: The apparent success of this undertaking put Mrs. Parker in excellent humor, and she invited the supposed crook to breakfast with her at the Broadway Central Hotel.

speaker: narrator
text: So far it will be observed P-Body had accomplished practically nothing. At breakfast, the girl inquired of her companion what his particular graft was, to which he replied that he was an expert second story man, and then proceeded to indulge his imagination in accounts of bold robberies in the brownstone districts, and the girl's

speaker: narrator
text: districts, and clever tricks in other cities, which left Mrs. Parker in no doubt that her companion was an expert gun of long experience. Then he took, as he expressed it, another chance.

speaker: narrator
text: Jim wanted me to tell you to put the gang-wise, said he. The girl looked at him sharply and contracted her brows. Gang, she exclaimed, what gang? Oh, perhaps he met Dutch and Swini.

speaker: narrator
text: P-Body bit his lip. He had had a close call. Don't know he replied he didn't say who they were just to put them wise.

speaker: narrator
text: A second time the detective had made a lucky hit, for Mrs. Parker suddenly laid aside all pretence and asked, do you want to make a lot of money? P-Body allowed that he did.

speaker: narrator
text: Do you know what they have got Jim for, asked the girl? Fony paper wasn't it? Yes, said Mrs. Parker, but Jim didn't write those checks. I wrote them myself.

speaker: narrator
text: If you want to go in with me, we can earn enough money to get Jim out, and you can do a good turn for yourself besides.

speaker: narrator
text: The detective's blood leapt in his veins, but he held himself under control as well as he could, and answered indifferently.

speaker: narrator
text: I guess not, and ever met a woman that was very good at that sort of game. Oh, you don't know me, she persisted, why I can copy anything in a few moments, really I can.

speaker: narrator
text: Too dangerous remarked P-Body, I might get settled for ten years. No, you wouldn't, she continued. It's the easiest thing in the world.

speaker: narrator
text: All you have to do is pick the mail out of some box on a corner. I can show you how, with a copper wire and a little piece of wax, and you are sure to find among the letters somebody's check in payment of a bill.

speaker: narrator
text: There at once you have the bank in the signature. Then all you have to do is write a letter to the bank asking for a new checkbook, saying yours is used up, and sign the name that appears on the check.

speaker: narrator
text: If you can fool the cashier into giving your messenger a checkbook, you can gamble pretty safely on his paying a check signed with the same name.

speaker: narrator
text: In that way you see, you can get all the blank checks you need and test the cashier's watchfulness at the same time. It's too easy.

speaker: narrator
text: The only thing you have to look out for is not to overdraw the account. Still, you find so many checks in the mail that you can usually choose somebody's account that will stand the strain.

speaker: narrator
text: Do you know, I have made hundreds of checks and the banks have certified every single one. P-Body laughed good naturally. Things were looking up a bit.

speaker: narrator
text: What do you think I am anyhow? He asked, I must look like a come-on. I'm given it to you straight, she said simply. After you've made out a good fat check, then you go to a store, buy something, tell them to forward the check to the bank for certification, and that you'll send for the goods in the change the next day.

speaker: narrator
text: The bank always certifies the check and you get the money. Not always, said P-Body with a grin. Now, not always, acquiesce Mrs. Parker.

speaker: narrator
text: But Jim and I have been averaging over $100 a day for months. Good graft alright, ascended the detective. But how does the one who lays down the check identify himself? For instance, suppose I go into Tiffany's and pick out a diamond and say I'm Mr. John Smith of 100 West 100th Street.

speaker: narrator
text: And the floor walker says, sorry Mr. Smith, but we don't know you. What then? Just flash a few letters on him, said the girl letters and envelopes. Where do you get them? Ask P-Body. Just write them silly and send them to yourself through the mail.

speaker: narrator
text: That's alright, retorted the second story man. But how can I mail myself a letter to 100 West 100th Street when I don't live there? Mrs. Parker smiled in a superior manner. I'm glad I can put you wise to a new game. I invented it myself. You want letters of identification, in different names and addresses on different days? Very good.

speaker: narrator
text: Buy a bundle of stamped envelopes and write your own name and address on them in pencil. When they arrive rub off the pencil address. Then if you want to be John Smith of 100 West 100th Street or anybody else, just address the cancelled envelope in ink.

speaker: narrator
text: Mabel said P-Body with admiration. You've got the gray matter all right. You can have me if you can deliver the rest of the goods.

speaker: narrator
text: There's still another little frill she continued, pleased to this compliment if you want to do the thing in style. Maybe he will find a letter or billhead in the mail at the same time that you get your sample check. If you do, you can have it copied and write your request for the checkbook and your order for the goods on paper printed exactly like it.

speaker: narrator
text: That gives a sort of final touch, you know. I remember we did that with a dentist named Bud at 137 West 22nd Street.

speaker: narrator
text: You've got all the rest whipped to a standstill, cried P-Body. Well, just come over to the room and I'll show you something worthwhile, exclaiming the girl getting up and paying their bill.

speaker: narrator
text: Now said she, when they were safely at West 38th Street and she had closed the door of the room and drawn P-Body to a desk in the bay window. Here's my regular handwriting.

speaker: narrator
text: She pulled towards her a pad which lay open upon the desk and wrote in a fair round hand, Mrs. James D. Singley.

speaker: narrator
text: This, she continued, changing her slant and dashing off a queer feminine scrawl, is the signature we fooled the Lincoln National Bank with, Miss Cousers, you know.

speaker: narrator
text: And this, she added a moment later, adopting a stiff, shaky humpbacked orthography, is the signature that got poor Jim into all this trouble.

speaker: narrator
text: And she inscribed twice upon the paper, the name E. Bierstadt. Poor Jim, she added to herself.

speaker: narrator
text: By George Mabel, remarked the detective, you're a wonder. See if you can copy my name.

speaker: narrator
text: And P-Body wrote the assumed name of William Hickey, first with a stub and then with a fine point, both of which signatures she copied like a flash.

speaker: narrator
text: In each case, however, being guilty of the lapse of spelling the word William, willian.

speaker: narrator
text: The pad now contained more than enough evidence to convict 20 women and P-Body, with the remark, you don't want to leave this kind of thing lying around Mabel, pretended to tear the page up, but substituted a blank sheet in its place and smuggled the precious bit of paper into his pocket.

speaker: narrator
text: Yes, I'll go into business with you, sure I will, said P-Body. And we'll get enough money to set Jim free, exclaimed the girl.

speaker: narrator
text: They were now fast friends, and it was agreed that Hickey should go and make himself presentable, after which they would dine at some restaurant and then sample a convenient mailbox.

speaker: narrator
text: Meantime P-Body telephoned to headquarters, and when the two set out for dinner at 6 o'clock, the supposed Hickey was stopped on Broadway by Detective Sargent Clark.

speaker: narrator
text: What are you doing here in New York, demanded Clark? Didn't I give you six hours to fly the coop, and who's this woman?

speaker: narrator
text: I was going, Clark, honest I was, wind Hickey, and this lady's alright, she hasn't done a thing.

speaker: narrator
text: Well, I guess I got a lock you up ahead quarters for the night, said Clark roughly, the girl can go.

speaker: narrator
text: Oh, Mr. Clark, do come and have dinner with us first, exclaimed Mrs. Parker. Mr. Hickey has been so very good to me, and he hasn't had anything to eat forever so long.

speaker: narrator
text: Don't care if I do, said Clark, I guess I can put up with the company if the board is good.

speaker: narrator
text: The three entered the Raleigh Hotel in order to substantial meal.

speaker: narrator
text: With the arrival of dessert, however, the girl became uneasy, and apparently fearing arrest herself, slipped a roll of bills under the table to Hickey, and whispered to him to keep it for her.

speaker: narrator
text: The detective, thinking that the farce had gone far enough, threw the money on the table and asked Clark to count it, at the same tune telling Mrs. Parker that she was in custody.

speaker: narrator
text: The girl turned white, uttered a little scream, and then regaining her self-possession remarked as nonchalantly as she pleased.

speaker: narrator
text: Well, clever as you think you are, you've destroyed the only evidence against me, my handwriting.

speaker: narrator
text: Not much remarked Peabody, producing the sheet of paper.

speaker: narrator
text: The girl saw that the game was up and made a mock-bow to the two detectives.

speaker: narrator
text: I take my hat off to the New York police, said she.

speaker: narrator
text: At this time, apparently, no thought of denying her guilt had entered her mind, and at the station house she's talked freely to the sergeant, the matron, and the various newspaper men who were present,

speaker: narrator
text: even drawing pictures of herself upon loose sheets of paper and signing her name, apparently rather enjoying the notoriety which her arrest had occasioned.

speaker: narrator
text: A thorough search of her apartment was now made with the result that several sheets of paper were found there, bearing what were evidently practiced signatures of the name Alice Couser.

speaker: narrator
text: Evidence was also obtained showing that on the day following her husband's arrest, she had destroyed large quantities of blank checkbooks and blank checks.

speaker: narrator
text: Upon the trial of Mrs. Parker, the handwriting experts testified that the beer-shot and Couser signatures were so perfect that it would be difficult to state that they were not originals.

speaker: narrator
text: The Parker woman was what is sometimes known as a freehand forger. She never traced anything, and as her forgeries were written by a muscular imitation of the pen movement of the writer of the genuine signature, they were almost impossible of detection.

speaker: narrator
text: When Albert T. Patrick forged the signature of Old Mr. Rice to the Sparious Will of 1900, and to the checks for $25,000, $65,000, and $135,000 upon Swenson's Bank, and the Fifth Avenue Trust Company, the forgeries were easily detected.

speaker: narrator
text: From the fact that as Patrick had traced them, they were all almost exactly alike and practically could be superimposed one upon another, line for line, dot for dot.

speaker: narrator
text: Mabel Parker's early history is shrouded in a certain amount of obscurity, but there is reason to believe that she was the offspring of respectable, laboring people, who turned her over while she was still an infant, to a Mr. Mrs. Prentice, instructors in physical culture in the public schools, first of St. Louis and later of St. Paul, Minnesota.

speaker: narrator
text: As a child and afterwards as a young girl, she exhibited great perocity and a considerable amount of real ability in drawing and in English composition, but her very cleverness and versatility were the means of her becoming much more sophisticated than most young women of her age, with the result that while still in her teens she gave her adopted parents ground for considerable easiness.

speaker: narrator
text: Accordingly, they decided to place her for the next few years in a convent near New York. By this time, she had attained a high degree of proficiency in writing short stories and miscellaneous articles, which she illustrated herself, for the papers and inferior magazines.

speaker: narrator
text: Convent life proved very dull for this young lady, and accordingly, one dark evening, she made her exit from the cloister by means of a conveniently located window.

speaker: narrator
text: Waiting for her in the grounds below was James Parker, 27 years old, already of a large criminal experience, although never yet convicted of crime. The two made their way to New York, were married and the girl entered upon her career.

speaker: narrator
text: Her husband, whose real name was James D. Singley, was a professional tenderloin crook, ready to turn his hand to any sort of cheap crime to satisfy his appetites and support life.

speaker: narrator
text: The money easily secured was easily spent, and singley at the time of his marriage was addicted to most of the vices common to the habituas of the underworld.

speaker: narrator
text: His worst enemy was the morphine habit, and from her husband Mrs. Singley speedily learned the use of the drug. At this time, Mabel Prentice Parker singley was about five feet two inches in height, weighing not more than 105 or 110 pounds.

speaker: narrator
text: Slander to girlishness and showing no maturity save in her face, which, with its high color, groy and blue eyes and her yellow hair, often led those who glanced at her casually to think her good looking.

speaker: narrator
text: Further inspection, however, revealed a fox-like expression, and irregularity in the position of the eyes, a hardness in the lines of the mouth, and a flatness of the nose, which belied the first impression.

speaker: narrator
text: This was particularly true, when, after being deprived of morphine in the tombs, her ordinary high color gave way at her second trial to a waxy paleness of complexion.

speaker: narrator
text: But the story of her career in the tenderloin would prove neither profitable nor attractive.

speaker: narrator
text: The subsequent history of the Parker case is a startling example of the credulity of the ordinary jury. The evidence secured was absolutely conclusive, but unfortunately,

speaker: narrator
text: juries are generally unwilling to take the uncorroborated word of a policeman against that of a defendant, particularly if the defendant be a young and pretty woman.

speaker: narrator
text: Here, at the very outset, was a complete confession on the part of Mrs. Parker, supplemented by illustrations from her own pen of what she could do.

speaker: narrator
text: Comparison showed that the signature she had written without a model upon the Peabody sheet were identical with those upon the forged checks and with Mr. Beerstadt's and Ms. Caliser's handwriting.

speaker: narrator
text: When Mrs. Parker's case therefore came on for pleading, her counsel, probably because they could think of nothing else to do, entered a plea of insanity.

speaker: narrator
text: It was also intimated that the young woman would probably plead guilty, and the case was therefore placed upon the calendar and moved for trial without much preparation on the part of the prosecution.

speaker: narrator
text: Instead of this young person confessing her guilt, however, she amused herself by ogling the jury and drawing pictures of the court, the district attorney, and the various witnesses.

speaker: narrator
text: Probably no more extraordinary scene was ever beheld in a court of law than not exhibited by part two of the general sessions upon Mabel Parker's first trial for forgery.

speaker: narrator
text: Attired in a sky blue dress and picture hat, with new white gloves, she sat jauntily by the side of her counsel throughout the proceedings, toying with her pen and pencil, and in the very presence of the jury copying handwriting which was given her for that purpose, by various members of the yellow press who crowded close behind the room.

speaker: narrator
text: From time to time she would dash off an aphorism or a paragraph in regard to the trial, which she handed to a reporter.

speaker: narrator
text: If satisfactory, this was elaborated and sometimes even illustrated by her for the evening edition of his paper.

speaker: narrator
text: The assistant district attorney complained that this was clearly a contemptive court, particularly as the defendant had drawn a picture not only of himself but of the presiding justice and a witness, which had appeared in one of the evening papers.

speaker: narrator
text: The court however did not see that anything could be done about it, and the girl openly continued her literary and artistic recreation.

speaker: narrator
text: The court itself was not a little amused at the actions of the defendant, and when detective P-body was called to the stand, the general hilarity had reached such a pitch that he was unable to give his testimony without smiling.

speaker: narrator
text: The natural result, therefore, at the first trial, was that the detective succeeded in giving the unqualified impression that he was drawing the long bow in a most preposterous fashion.

speaker: narrator
text: At the conclusion of the people's case, the evidence that Mrs. Parker had forged the checks amounted simply to this, that an officer who was greatly interested in her conviction had sworn to a most astonishing series of facts from which the jury must infer that this exceedingly is a stuute young person had not only been entirely a witness,

speaker: narrator
text: but not only been entirely and completely deceived by a detective, but also that at almost their first meeting she confessed to him in detail the history of her crimes.

speaker: narrator
text: Practically the only other evidence tending to corroborate his story were a few admissions of a similar character made by her to newspaper men, matrons and officers at the police station.

speaker: narrator
text: Unless the jury were to believe that Mrs. Parker had actually written the signatures on the P-body sheet, there was no evidence that she was the actual forger, hence upon P-body's word alone depended the verdict of the jury.

speaker: narrator
text: The trouble with the case was that it was too strong, too good, to be entirely credible, and had there been no defense it is exceedingly probable that the trial would have resulted in an acquittal, since the prosecution had elected to go to the jury upon the question of whether or not the defendant had been a witness.

speaker: narrator
text: Mrs. Parker however had withdrawn her plea of insanity and determined to put on a defense, which proved in its turn to be even more extraordinary than the case against her.

speaker: narrator
text: This in brief was to the effect that she had known P-body to be a police officer all along, but that it had occurred to her that if she could deceive him into believing that it was she herself who had committed the forgeries, her husband might get off,

speaker: narrator
text: and that later she might in turn establish her own innocence. She had therefore hastily scratched her name at the top of a sheet already containing her husband's handwriting and it told P-body that the signatures had been written by herself.

speaker: narrator
text: That the sheet had been written in the officer's presence, she declared to be a pure invention on his part to secure her conviction.

speaker: narrator
text: She told her extremely illogical story with a certain win some naivete which carried an air of semi-probability with it.

speaker: narrator
text: From her deportment on the stand, one would have taken her for a boarding school miss who, in some inconsequent fashion, had gotten mixed up in a frolic for which no really logical explanation could be given.

speaker: narrator
text: Then the door in the back of the courtroom opened and James Parker was led to the bar where in the presence of the jury he pleaded guilty to the forgery of the very signature for which his wife was standing trial.

speaker: narrator
text: He was then sworn as a witness, took the stand and testified that he had written all the forged signatures to the checks, including the signatures upon the P-body sheet.

speaker: narrator
text: The district attorney found himself in an embarrassing position. If Parker was the forger, why not challenge him to write the forged signatures upon the witness stand and thus to prove his alleged capacity for so doing?

speaker: narrator
text: The obvious objection to this was that Parker, an anticipation of this test, had probably been practicing the signature in the tombs for months.

speaker: narrator
text: On the other hand, if the district attorney did not challenge him to write the signatures, the defense would argue that he was afraid to do so, and that as Parker had sworn himself to be the forger, it was not incumbent upon the defense to prove it further, that it was a matter for cross-examination.

speaker: narrator
text: With considerable hesitation, the prosecuting attorney asked Parker to write the couser signature, which was the one set forth in the indictment charging the forgery, and after much backing and filling on the part of the witness, who ingeniously complained that he was in a bad nervous condition, owing to the lack of morphine, in consequence of which his hand trembled, and he was in no condition to write forgeries.

speaker: narrator
text: The latter took his pen and managed to make a very fair copy of the couser signature from memory, good enough in fact to warrant a jury informing the conclusion that he was in fact the forger, this close to the case.

speaker: narrator
text: The defense claimed that it was clear that James Parker was the forger since he had admitted it in an open court, pleaded guilty to the indictment, and proved that he had the capacity.

speaker: narrator
text: The prosecution, upon the other hand, argued that the evidence was conclusive, that the defendant herself was the writer of the check.

speaker: narrator
text: The whole thing boiled down to whether or not the jury was going to believe that Mrs. Parker had written the peabody sheet in the presence of the detective.

speaker: narrator
text: When her husband claimed that, with the exception of Mabel's signature, he had done it himself and carelessly left the paper in his desk in the room.

speaker: narrator
text: The prosecuting attorney was at his wit's end for an argument to meet the fact that Parker had written the sample forgery of the couser signature before the very eyes of the jury.

speaker: narrator
text: He found it at last in an offer on his own part in open court, during his summing up, to write for the jury from memory a better forgery of the couser signature than that written by Parker himself, and thus to show how simple a matter it was to learn to do so.

speaker: narrator
text: He had taken up his pen and was about to give a sample of his handiwork in this respect, when the defendant grasped her counsel's arm and whispered, for God's sake, don't let him do it.

speaker: narrator
text: Whereupon the lawyer arose and objected, saying that such evidence was improper as the case was closed.

speaker: narrator
text: As might have been expected under the circumstances, considering the blunders of the prosecution, and the ingenuous appearance of the defendant, the trial ended in a disagreement the jury's standing eight to four for acquittal.

speaker: narrator
text: The District Attorney's Office now took up a thorough investigation of the case. With the result that on a second prosecution, Mrs. Parker was confronted with a massive evidence, which it was impossible for her to refute.

speaker: narrator
text: A boy named Wallace Sweeney, sentenced to the Elmira reformatory, was found to have been an active accomplice of the parkers for several years, and he was accordingly brought down to New York where he gave a complete history of his relations with them.

speaker: narrator
text: His story proved beyond any doubt that Mrs. Parker was the forger of the checks in the possession of the District Attorney, and of many others beside, some of them for very large amounts.

speaker: narrator
text: The evidence of Sweeney was of itself quite sufficient to warrant a conviction. To make assurance doubly sure, however, the District Attorney upon the second trial moved a new indictment, setting forth as the forgery a check signed at E. Bierstadt,

speaker: narrator
text: so that when Parker took the stand as he had done in the former trial and testified that he was the forger, he found himself unable to write this new signature, and hence his testimony went for nothing.

speaker: narrator
text: But even the testimony of Sweeney was that of an accomplice requiring corroboration, while that of Peabody remained the evidence of a mere policeman, eager to convict the defendant and add another scalp to his official belt.

speaker: narrator
text: With an extraordinary accumulation of evidence, the case hinged on the veracity of these two men, to which was opposed the denial of the defendant and her husband.

speaker: narrator
text: It is an interesting fact that in the final analysis of the case, the jury were compelled to determine the issue by evidence entirely documentary in character.

speaker: narrator
text: It is also an illustration of what tiny facts stamp whole masses of testimony as true or false.

speaker: narrator
text: On her examination, Mrs. Parker had sworn among other things, one that she had no knowledge of the envelope, the back of which had been used by Parker for the purpose of directing Rogers Pete and Company to deliver the clothes and money to his messenger, and of course that the words Mr. George B. Lang were not in her handwriting.

speaker: narrator
text: This was one of the envelopes claimed by the prosecution, two have been originally addressed in pencil and sent to themselves by the parkers through the mail for this precise purpose.

speaker: narrator
text: Two, that she had never seen the calzour practice sheets, and that the words Alice Calzour repeated hundreds of times thereon were not in her handwriting.

speaker: narrator
text: For some reason, unknown to the district attorney, however, she admitted to having written the words, I am upstairs in the bathroom upon a similar sheet, proclaimed that at the time this was done, the reverse of the paper was entirely blank.

speaker: narrator
text: Microscopic examination showed that among the words Alice and Calzour on the practice sheets, someone had written a capital M, one of the legs of the M crossed and was superimposed upon a letter in the word Alice.

speaker: narrator
text: Hence, whoever wrote the M knew what was on the practice sheet, an enlargement of this M and a comparison of it with the M in the defendant's signature to her formal examination in the police court, with the M in Mr. in the address on the envelope, and with that in the Mrs. on the Peabody sheet, rendered it obvious that they were all written by one in the same hand.

speaker: narrator
text: Therefore, it was clear that the defendant was familiar with the contents of the practice sheets, even if she had not written them herself, and had not told the truth in this regard.

speaker: narrator
text: Moreover, it was fairly easy to see that the same hand that had written the words I am upstairs in the bathroom upon the second practice sheet had at the same time and with the same pen, written the rest of the sheet.

speaker: narrator
text: This was clearly perceptible on examining the ease and ease, a comparison of the address Mr. George B. Lang with the name Mrs. James D. Singley also shows clearly that one in the same person wrote them both, and to the accuracy of all these self-evident propositions, a leading handwriting expert in New York added his unqualified opinion.

speaker: narrator
text: Thus, but for a little carelessness in failing to destroy oddscrap of paper, and to disguise her penmanship, which it seemed to her quite unnecessary to do, as in the address of B. Lang and the Lope, Mrs. Parker might well have gone free after all.

speaker: narrator
text: It is impossible to describe all the varied dramatic features of this interest in case. No one who is present is likely to forget the impression made by the defendant at her second trial,

speaker: narrator
text: when in defiance of overwhelming proof she still struggled to vindicate herself. Her counsel contended throughout the trial that she was a hitherto innocent young woman, led astray and started upon a criminal career by a rascally husband, whom she still loved evodedly, and for whose sake she had prepared to confess herself a criminal.

speaker: narrator
text: The James Parker introduced his wife to a life of crime, there can be no doubt, but that she had a natural predilection for it must be equally obvious.

speaker: narrator
text: It is probably true that Mabel Parker's affection for her convict husband was unfained and deep. The natural repugments of the American jury for convicting a woman was shown when, in spite of the overwhelming proof upon the Parker woman's second trial, the jury remained out eight hours and then found her guilty of uttering only with a strong recommendation for mercy.

speaker: narrator
text: She was sentenced to the Bedford Reformatory.

speaker: narrator
text: End of chapter 1. Recording by Colleen McMahon.

speaker: narrator
text: The End of chapter 2. Recording by Colleen McMahon.
